loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Zeinab

texts.en:
Zeinab, 52, is a widow that lives with her two children in Saida, a city in southern Lebanon.  Zeinab has owned a clothing shop for 10 years.  Her clients are her friends, neighbors and others.  When Zeinab first started her business, she faced social and economic conditions.   

She requests a loan for $1000 USD from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her shop.  This will be her third loan, and she has always repaid her loans on time.

loans.use: Zeinab will use the loan to purchase merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina A. is fifty years old. She is widow and the mother of seven children. Georgina is resourceful and enterprising. She has supported three children to graduation from high school through her business. She operates a local restaurant and sells local foods like “fufu” and “banku” along with drinks. Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantain with mortar and pestle, which is taken with soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and it is taken with hot pepper or soup. She says her working capital is inadequate and barely support her business.

With the loan, she wants to inject additional capital into the business to scale up production and maintain quality. Precisely, she would buy more ingredients like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. As a single parent, Georgina believes your support to her business progress would eventually increase her ability to educate the rest of her children to higher levels.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and drinks for her restaurant.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah K. is 42 years old. She is married and has given birth to four children. All are attending school in Nkawkaw in the Ashanti region of Ghana, where they stay. She is a crop farmer who produces food items such as maize and plantain. She has being farming for the past four years on five hectares of land in the village. In 2007, she was fortunately adjourned the best farmer in her town and she was given a prize. Hannah said initially it was very tough for her, until she met Sinapi, because she did not have adequate funds to buy chemicals to spray the farm. She produces in a large quantity and retails to food suppliers. She also sells at the market square during the market days.

With this loan, she wants to buy more farm supplies and employ more hands on her farm to achieve greater yields this year. In this way, she can supply to a large number of customers to increase her market size, hence, her profit margin. Hannah dreams of providing high quality education for her kids and this dream also depends on you to materialize. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Otunoi

texts.en: M. Otunoi was born in 1971 in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan. She is married with 2 children. Otunoi dreamed of higher education but becouse of her economic situation it was impossible to get it so now she tries to work hard to ensure a good future for her children. She dreams of seeing her son as a doctor in future. Otunoi works in the Khujand local bazaar where she trades shoes. She comes every day to Khujand to trade and earn money. She works with suppliers from China and Uzbekistan. Otunoi applies to KIVA to ask for a  business development loan of 1500 STJ for 1 month for the seasonal assortment importing and business turnover increase.

loans.use: seasonal assortment importing and business turnover increase

loans.name: Mamlakat

texts.en:
Mamlakat I. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and their 4 children. She operates a business growing and selling garden produce like grapes. Thanks to help from her husband and their children, as well as her own dedication and persistence, the business has grown considerably, from uncultivated land to a large garden. Now Mamlakat is requesting 3200 Somoni ($ 925 USD). She will buy fertilizer and prepare her garden for the upcoming season so that she can provide the quality of produce that her customers expect. Let’s help this mother keep working for the well being of her family.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah A. is a 48 year old trader. She is married and the mother of six children, who are all currently in school. She trades tomatoes and other vegetables on top of a table in the local market of Konongo Agogo in the Ashanti region of Ghana, where she lives. She says that through this business she has endeavored to support three of the kids to finish senior high school.

She requests this loan to enable her buy increased stock of tomatoes to grow and scale up her business progress. She hopes to increase her profit margin to enable her save more to support her family, especially her children's education.

loans.use: To buy increased stock of tomatoes.

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
M. Hussein is 43 years old. He is married to a primary school teacher with 4 school-going children between the ages of 18-25. Besides his career as a head teacher, M. runs a grocery shop in Kamuli town. He earns a profit of Ush 200,000 per month from which he pays rent of Ush 700,000 per year. 

To fit into his busy work schedule, he has one employee. The loan is helping M. to expand his business by purchasing eggs, utensils, cutlery and soft drinks. He dreams of running a supermarket and also seeing his children through all levels of education successfully.

loans.use: Purchasing eggs, utensils, cutlery and soft drinks.

loans.name: Assanatou

texts.fr:
Madame  Assanatou D.  a 30 ans, mère d’un (1) enfant, elle réside avec son époux et leur enfant à Wayerma II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Assanatou D. est une enseignante de profession, en parallèle avec sa profession elle dispose d’une boutique devant le domicile conjugal où elle mène cette activité d’achat et de vente  d’articles divers (Cigarette, bonbon, allumette, Cheew Gum, lait en poudre, Thé, sucre, etc) il y a maintenant dix (10) ans. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant cinq (5) ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association de femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 5ème prêt individuel commerçant (PIC), tous correctement remboursés.
 Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 5 cartouches de  différentes sortes de Cigarettes,  1 carton du thé, 1 sac du sucre, 10 paquets de bonbon, 10 paquets de Cheew Gum, 20 paquets d’allumette, etc.  Madame  Assanatou D. vend ses marchandises au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée des voisins.
Elle achète ses marchandises auprès des commerçants grossistes de la place avant de les revendre en détail.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 80 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Assanatou D. is 30 years old and the mother of one child. She lives with her husband and their child in Wayerma II, a popular neighborhood in Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mrs. Assanatou D. is a trained teacher who also runs a small shop outside her home, where she's been reselling various articles (cigarettes, candies, matches, chewing gum, powdered milk, tea, sugar, etc) for ten years. She's much in demand thanks to the quality of her products. To meet an ever-increasing customer demand, she decided to join the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso five years ago. After several solidarity loans (group loans) with other women of her neighborhood, she's now seeking her fifth individual commercial loan (PIC loan). All previous loans were repaid without problems. With this new loan, she intends to buy 5 cartons of diverse brands of cigarettes, 1 box of tea, 1 sack of sugar, 10 packs of candies, 10 packs of chewing gums, 20 packs of cigarettes, etc. Mrs. Assanatou D. sells her products for cash or on credit to a clientele of neighbors. She purchases the goods she retails from wholesalers in Sikasso. With this loan, she anticipates turning a monthly profit of XOF 80'000 (ca. US$ 160), to be mainly used to help with the family expenses and to repay the loan. The remainder will be invested in her business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell various items (cigarettes, chewing gum, sugar, etc)

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah N. is 32 years old, married with 4 children of whom one is in school. This hardworking lady sells motor spare parts in Iganga town. She earns an average of Ush 500,000 profits per month, from which she pays Ush 100,000 monthly rent. The loan proceeds are helping Sarah purchase yana tyres, and some brake pads.

Based on her 5 years' experience in the business, Sarah now dreams of opening up a number of spare parts outlets around the country hoping the income from the business will enable her to build a modern residence for her family.

loans.use: To purchase yana tyres and some brake pads.

loans.name: Mouhinatou

texts.fr: K. Mouhinatou est née le 3 aout 1962. Elle s’est marié avec HOUNKONNOU Edmond.  Elle a fini les études jusqu’au secondaire. Elle a 3 enfants – 22, 15, et 7 ans, tous scolarisés. Elle a mené son activité depuis 27 ans. Elle achète le lait aux éleveurs, et elle fabrique le fromage. Elle vend sa fromage a Tokpa. Elle aussi vend les fruits comme les avocats, les bananes, et les tomates fraiches sur places. Elle a une troisième commerce en vendant les chaussures dans le quartier Aglas. Elle a besoin d’acheter a crédit pour gérer ses activités. Avec ses crédits de Kiva, elle a pu mieux économiser. Dans l’avenir elle voudrait acheter en gros, acheter une maison pour louer, et rendre le refinancement des prêts plus rapide.
texts.en:
Mouhinatou K. was born on the 3rd August 1962. She is married to Edmond Hounkonnou. She finished her high school studies and has 3 children, aged 22, 15 and 7, who have all attended school. She has worked for 27 years buying milk from farmers and making cheese, which she sells in Tokpa. She also sells fruit such as avocados, bananas and fresh tomatoes. She has a third business selling shoes in the Aglas district. She buys on credit to manage her businesses. With her loans from Kiva she has been able to make more savings. In the future she would like to be able to buy products in bulk, to buy a house to rent and to repay her loans more quickly.

Translated from French by Holly Miller, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fruit

loans.name: Diadiaratou

texts.fr:
Madame  Diadiaratou B. a 36 ans et vit dans une grande famille avec son époux et ses six (6) enfants (4 garçons et 2 filles) à Banconi, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame  Diadiaratou B.  après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, elle s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et de vente d’huile alimentaire il y a maintenant douze (12) ans. Elle mène son activité au domicile et au marché de son quartier où elle dispose une grande table sur laquelle elle vend ses marchandises. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant cinq (5) ans. Après 2 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association de femmes de son quartier (Association Soro yiriwa de Banconi), elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel commerçant (PIC) , tous correctement remboursés.
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 18 bidons d’huile alimentaire. Elle achète ses marchandises dans les huiléries de la place. Vue le positionnement de son quartier, Madame  Diadiaratou B.  fait beaucoup de ventes, au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée des femmes surtout lors des cérémonies (mariage, baptème, etc.). 
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour , contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Diadiaratou B. is 36 years old and lives in a large family with her husband and their six children (four boys and two girls) in Banconi, one of the suburbs of Sikasso, in Mali. Twelve years ago Diadiaratou B. began buying and selling edible, after having unsuccessfully tried a number of businesses. She sells from home and from her local market where she has a large table from which to sell her merchandise. She is very sought-after by her customers because of the quality of her products. To satisfy her increasing number of clients, she decided five years ago to join the microfinancial institution Soro Yiriwaso. After two loans as part of a neighbourhood businesswomen's association, the Soro Yiriwaso Association of Banconi, she is now asking for her fourth individual loan. All her previous loans were repaid. She will buy 18 drums of edible oil. She buys her merchandise in the local oil mills. Given the location of her neighbourhood, Diadiaratou B. has good sales. Her customers are mainly women during times of ceremonies such as weddings, baptisms and so on. She expects that this loan will allow her a monthly income of 90,000 FCFA with which she will contribute to the household expenses, pay the loan interest, and invest the remainder in her business.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy edible oil for resale.

loans.name: Hamisi

texts.en:
Hamisi N. is 45 years old and married with 8 children between the ages of 2 and 17 years, of whom 6 are in schools. He is a hard-working and determined miller in Buwenge town. The loan proceeds are helping him purchase more maize, cassava and sorghum for milling. After milling the different types of flour, he sells to the retailers within the area.

He has 7 years experience in the business and thus dreams of purchasing more milling machines so as to open up new outlets in the region. On average, he earns a monthly profit of Ush 3000,000 from which he pays annual rent of Ush 400,000. When his business plans succeed, he would love to educate his children to university levels.

loans.use: Purchase more maize, cassava and sorghum for milling.

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr: A. Madeleine est née a 1970. Elle est veuve et elle a 3 enfants – 16, 13, et 10 ans. Elle n’a pas eu l’occasion d’aller a l’école, mais deux de ses enfants sont scolarisés. Elle a commencé son commerce il y a 21 ans avec la vente de la farine de manioc, l’igname, et le mais. Actuellement, elle fabrique sa propre fromage, et elle achète les crains de soja et le manioc au Marche Dantokpa. Avant les crédits de Kiva elle a acheté en détaille, mais grâce au crédit elle peut acheter en gros. Le crédit lui a permis de garder ses revenus pour les frais de scolarité. Elle voudrait focaliser sur la vente des vivres dans l’avenir parce que le feu n’est pas bon pour sa santé.
texts.en:
Madeleine A., born in 1970, is a widow with three children, ages 16, 13, and 10. She didn't have the opportunity to go to school, but two of her children are in school. She started her business 21 years ago selling cassava flour, yams, and corn. Currently, she makes her own cheese, and she buys soybeans and cassava at the Dantokpa Marketplace. Before Kiva loans, she bought at the retail level, but thanks the loan, she can buy wholesale. Her loan will enable her to reserve her income for covering schooling costs. She would like to focus on selling staple foods in the future because fire is not good for one's health.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soybeans and cassava

loans.name: Dramane

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Dramane K. est âgé de 31 et vit avec son épouse et leurs enfants  dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Wayerma I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur  Dramane K.  après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, il s’initie à cette activité d’achat et de vente de bazins blancs, de la  soude caustique, des teintures, etc. depuis maintenant trois (03) ans. Il mène son activité en face de  l’AMAP de Sikasso (Agence Malienne pour la Presse et la Publicité), non loin de la prison centrale où il dispose d’une boutique. Monsieur K. est beaucoup sollicité.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, Il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant un (01) an avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter 10 piéces de bazin, 5 boîtes de teinture de couleur differentes, 10 paquets de soude caustique et 3 sacs de potasse, etc. 
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako et les revend a une clientèle composée généralement des femmes teiturières de Sikasso.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 110 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour, résoudre certaines de ses dépenses personnelles, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Dramane K. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and their children in a large, traditional, extended family in Wayerma I, one of the working-class districts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having done many kinds of work without success, he got started three years ago in buying and selling plain damask cloth, caustic soda, dyes, etc. He works across from the AMAP de Sikasso (the Malian agency for the press and advertising), not far from the central prison, where he has a shop. He is in high demand.

Concerned about improving satisfaction in his burgeoning customer base, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso a year ago. He is on his first individual loan. With this loan, he intends to buy 10 lengths of damask, 5 containers of dyes of different colors, 10 packets of caustic soda, and 3 sacks of potash, etc. He gets his supplies in Bamako and resells his goods to customers generally composed of the women dyers of Sikasso.

With this loan, he envisions realizing a monthly profit of 110,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to resolve certain personal expenses of his, to help cover family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy plain damask, caustic soda, dyes, potash, etc.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George O. O., 35, runs a cosmetics shop in Bugiri town.  The loan is helping him replenish his stock of braids and hair relaxers to meet the demands of his customers.  Good customer courtesy and quality products purchased directly from the licensed suppliers has kept O.’s business running.  He makes an average profit of Ush 60,000 per week. 

He is married to Nasirumbi Christine, a head teacher at Bukooli college Bugiri with whom he has a 3 months old daughter.  O.’s goals are to expand his business into wholesale stores and to use the income from the business to pay for his daughter's education at all levels.

loans.use: Purchase braids and hair relaxers .

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata C. a 38 ans et réside avec son époux et ses quatre (4) enfants (1 garçon et 3 filles) à Sanoubougou I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Fatoumata C.  après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, elle s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et de vente  d’habillements (bazins et foulards légers teintés) il y a maintenant plus de dix (10) ans. Elle met les bazins et les foulards légers dans la teinture. Elle  a appris cette  activité auprès d’une amie. Elle dispose une place à la gare routière de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée. Vue le positionnement de sa place, son activité marche en merveille avec une clientele composée essentiellement des routiers et d’employers travaillant à ce niveau. 
Dans ses recherches de ressources finanacières complémentaires, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant trois (3) ans. Après 3 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association BADEYA de Sanoubougou I), elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel commerçant (PIC) tous correctement remboursés.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 18 pièces de bazins, 50 paquets de foulards légers, 5 sachets de soude caustique et 5 boîtes de couleurs differentes. Elle achète les bazins,la soude caustique et les couleurs sur place et les foulards à Niono sur commande.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 80 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce et contribuer aux dépenses familiales..
texts.en:
Ms. Fatoumata C. is 38 years old and resides with her husband and her four children (one boy and three girls) in Sanoubougou I, one of the working-class districts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having done many kinds of work without success, she became initiated in this work selling clothing (damask cloth and dyed light-weight scarfs) ten years ago now. She puts the damask and scarves into dyes, which she learned to do from a friend. She has a spot at the Sikasso bus station, where she is in high demand. Because of this location, her business is doing superbly, with her customers composed essentially of drivers and employees working there. In her search for supplemental financial resources, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After three solidarity loans (group loans), all correctly repaid, with a women's association in her district (Association BADEYA de Sanoubougou I), she is on her second PIC (an individual commercial loan). She intends to use this loan to buy 18 lengths of damask, 50 packets of scarves, 5 bags of caustic soda, and 5 containers dyes of different colors. She buys the damask, caustic soda, and dyes locally, and the scarves -- in Niono by special order. With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 80,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to increase her working capital and to help cover family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace B., 50, is a hardworking business lady that sells bicycle spare parts in the Mpanga market.  She is expanding her business by using the loan to purchase bicycle tires, carriers, mudguard, seat covers and rims.  

She is married with seven children, all of which are in school.  Grace plans to expand her retail shop into a wholesale shop.  When this dream comes true, she will be in a position to build a modern residential house for her family.

loans.use: Purchase bicycle tires, carriers, mudguard, seat covers and rims.

loans.name: Haoua

texts.fr:
Madame   Haoua T. a 59 ans et vit dans une grande famille avec son époux et ses six (6) enfants (1 garçon et 5 filles) à Wayerma I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Haoua T. n‘ayant pas eu la chance de progresser à l’école , elle s’interesa aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente des  friperies il y a maintenant plus de vingt (20) ans. Elle mène son activité de façon ambulante à Sikasso où elle a une grande réputation et une notoriété hors paire. 
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant cinq (5) ans. Après 6 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association de femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 9ème prêt individuel commerçant (PIC) tous correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 3 balles de friperie de qualités différentes (draps, napéron, serviette, etc.). Elle achète ses marchandises sur place avec les grossistes avant de les revendre de services en services  au comptant et  crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce et faire face aux dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Madam Haoua T. is 41 years old and lives in a large family with her husband and her six children (one boy and five girls) in Wayerma I, one of the working-class districts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having had the chance to make progress in school, she got interested 20 year ago in income-generating work, notably commerce in second-hand clothing. She goes door-to-door in Sikasso, where she has a great reputation and outstanding fame.

To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso five years ago. After six solidarity loans (group loans), all correctly repaid, with a women's assocation in her district, she is on her ninth PIC (a commercial individual loan). She intends to use this loan to buy 3 bales of different sheets, mats, napkins, etc. She buys her goods locally from wholesalers and then resells them from agency to agency, cash or credit accepted.

With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to increase her working capital and to cope with family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy used clothing

loans.name: Houleye

texts.fr:
Madame Houleye D. a 47 ans, veuve et vit dans la maison de son defunt époux avec ses enfants à Sanoubougou II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elle s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et de vente d’huile alimentaire il y a maintenant dix (10) ans. Elle mène son activité a la maison et au marché de son quartier où elle dispose une place.
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle decida de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant cinq (5) ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association JEKAFO de Sanoubougou II), elle est à son 5ème prêt individuel commerçant (PIC)  tous correctement remboursés. Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 2 fûts d’huile alimentaire au niveau des différentes  huiléries de place avant de les revendre en détail.  Madame Houleye D. vend ses marchandises au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée de  femmes. 
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Madam Houleye D. is 47 years old, a widow, and lives in the house of her deceased husband with her children in Sanoubougou II, one of the working-class districts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She got started in this commerce selling vegetable oil ten years ago. She works at home and at the marketplace in her district where she has a spot.

To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, she decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso five years ago. After four solidarity loans (group loans), all correctly repaid, with a women's association in her district (Association JEKAFO de Sanoubougou II) , she is now on her fifth PIC (an individual merchant loan).

She intends to use this loan to buy two barrels of vegetable oil from different oil suppliers locally and then resell them retail. Ms. D. sells her goods to customers composed of women, cash or credit accepted. She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA, which will be used essentially to help cover family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetable oil

loans.name: Korotoumou

texts.fr:
Madame Korotoumou K. N. a 26 ans et vit dans une famille polygame avec son époux, sa coepouse et leurs enfants à Wayerma I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Korotoumou K. N. n’ayant pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école, après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, elle décida de s’initier aux activités d’achat et de vente d’habillements (pagne Wax, tissus brodés, bazins teintés, etc.)  il y a maintenant plus de trois (3) ans. Elle mène son activité de façon ambulante et souvent à côté d’une amie au grand marche de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clienèle pour la qualité de ses produits.
 Dans ses recherches de ressources financières afin de satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, elle décida de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant deux (2) mois avec qui elle est à son premier prêt individuel commerçant (PIC). 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 5 complets de bazins teintés, 5 pièces de pagnes Wax et 5 pièces de tissus brodés. Elle achète ses bazins teintés à Bamako(capitale du Mali), les tissus brodés et  pagnes Wax à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso) et les revend de facon ambulante à une clientele composée généralement de femmes surtout lors des cérémonies (baptème, mariage, etc.).
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Madam Korotoumou K. N. is 26 years old and lives in a polygamous family with her husband, co-wives, and their children in Wayerma I, one of the working-class districts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having had the chance to attend school and after doing many kind of work without success, she decided to become initiated in buying and selling clothing (Wax pagnes, embroidered fabrics, dyed damask, etc.) over three years ago. She goes door-to-door and often works with a friend at the grand marketplace of Sikasso where she is in high demand by her customers for the quality of her goods.

In her search for financial resources for her clearly growing customer base, she decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two months ago. She is on her first PIC (a commercial individual loan). She intends to use this loan to buy 5 suits of dyed damask, 5 lengths of Wax pagnes (high-grade colorful West African cloth), and 5 lengths of embroidered fabrics. She buys her dyed damask in Bamako (capital of Mali), the embroidered fabrics and Wax pagnes in Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso), and she resells them door-to-door to customers, generally composed of women, especially during ceremonies (baptisms, marriages, etc.)

With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to help cover family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en: Deborah U. is a hair stylist.  She also sells hair extensions and hair creams in her shop.  She is 26 years old and married.  She lives in Afro-Ajamgbadi, Lagos state, Nigeria.  She hopes for a N140,000 loan to purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell.  She says thank you to all the Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions  and hair cream to sell.

loans.name: Steven

texts.en: M. Steven is a determined and hardworking business man in Kaboyo-Rubindi.  He sells water heaters, taps and pipes.  This loan will help him replenish his stock by purchasing more taps and water heaters.  He is 50 years old and married with six children.  Steven’s dream is to open up a hardware shop in his community.  He also desires to see all his children finish school successfully.

loans.use: Purchasing more taps and water heaters.

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Né le 07 Août 1978, Monsieur Mamadou T. vit avec son épouse et son enfant dans la grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Sanoubougou II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Mamadou T. après l’obtention de D.E.F(diplôme d’études fondamentales) ne fut pas orienté. Il vint ainsi aux activités génératrices de revenus. Il tenta plusieurs activités sans succès, alors décide de s’initier au commerce de téléphones portables et de leurs accessoires (façade, battérie, chargeur, écouteur, etc.) depuis maintenant  cinq (5) ans. Il mène son activité au carrefour du nouveau marché de Médine où il dispose d’une boutique. Monsieur T. est beaucoup sollicité par sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, Il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant cinq (5) mois. Il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter  5 téléphones portables, 1 carton de façades, 1 carton de carton de battéries, 10 chargeurs et 1 douzaine d’écouteurs, etc. Il s’approvisionne à Bamako(capitale du Mali) et les revend à une clientèle composée généralement de jeunes et surtout de forains.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on August 8, 1978, Mr. Mamadou T. lives with his wife and child in a large, traditional, extended family in Sanoubougou II, one of the working-class districts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After obtaining his D.E.F. (a middle-school diploma), he had no direction. He thus came to earning an income. He tried several kinds of work without success and then decided to become initiated in the commerce of mobile phones and accessories (handset skins, batteries, chargers, earphones, etc.) five years ago now. He works at the crossroads of the new marketplace of Médine where he has a shop. He is in high demand by his customers for the quality of his goods.

Concerned about improving satisfaction in his burgeoning customer base, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso five months ago. He is on his first individual loan. With it, he intends to buy 5 mobile phones, 1 box of skins, 1 box of batteries, 10 chargers, and 1 dozen earphones, etc. He gets his goods in Bamako (capital of Mali) and resells them to customers generally composed of young people and especially vendors.

With this loan, he envisions realizing a monthly profit of 120,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to pay the loan interest and to invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy mobile phones and accessories

loans.name: Nèkè

texts.fr:
Né vers 1979 à Kocoula Sous Préfecture de San (région de Ségou), Monsieur Nèkè D. est un  monogame résidant avec son épouse et leurs 2 enfants à Wayerma I  un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur  Neke D. n’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école très tôt il entreprena les activités génératrices. Après  s’être éssayé à beaucoup d’activités sans succès, il décida de faire son job  l’activité blanchisserie depuis maintenant  sept (7) ans. Il mène son activité au carrefour de la Rue Pekin de son quartier où il dispose son atelier de blanchisserie. Pour sa dextérité et sa ponctualité il est très sollicité et apprécié de tous ses clients qui se cessent  d’augmenter.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant dix (10) mois dont il est à son premier prêt individuel. Il sollicite ce premier prêt pour acheter un (1) fer électrique et une (1) moto Jakarta pour pouvoir récuperer et livrer les habits de ses clients qui  sont un peu loin de son atelier.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 135 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born around 1979 in Kocoula in the sub-prefecture of San (region of Ségou), Nèkè D. lives in a monogamous relationship with his wife and their two children in Wayerma I, a populous neighbourhood of the city of Sikasso in Mali. Nèkè D. did not have the opportunity to go to school: he worked from a very young age. For seven years he has been offering laundry services, a business he started after a number of unsuccessful attempts at other work. His business is located at the corner of Pekin Road in his neighbourhood. Because of his dexterity and punctuality, he is popular with all his customers and continues to attract more clients. Ten months ago, in order to satisfy his customers, he decided to join the microfinancial institution Soro Yiriwaso. This will be his first individual loan. He is asking for this loan to buy an electric iron and a Jakarta motorbike in order to pick up and deliver the clothing of those customers who live far from his workshop. With this loan, he expects to make 135,000 FCFA monthly with which he will increase his business, contribute to the household expenses, pay the interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy an electric iron and a Jakarta motorbike

loans.name: Khanimaga

texts.en: Khanimaga A. has an established business selling kids' toys in her store in the southern city of Azerbaijan called Imishli. She started her business about seven years ago. She has an entrepreneurial mind, and she has worked hard to develop her business. Buying inventory from Baku city, where she can get better prices, is one way in which she is able to gain a competitive business advantage. Khanimaga is married, and she has four children. One of her goals for the future is to provide all of her children with good living conditions and an education. Khanimaga is requesting a loan of 1200 USD in order to purchase more toys to sell in her store. She will be able to increase her sales and will continue to provide a better life for herself and her family.

loans.use: Increase her inventory of children's toys

loans.name: Arif

texts.en: Arif G. is a young and energetic guy who wants to improve his family's living conditions. He is 37 years old and lives in the small village of Saatli, Azerbaijan. He has a retail shop where sells spare parts for cars made in Russia. He has been involved in this business for more than 13 years, helping his relatives before he opened his shop. He provides spare parts for cars and provides his family with food and other necessities. There is a great demand for Arif`s spare parts, so he wants to buy more goods to meet his clients' demands. He wants to take out a loan of 1200 US dollars to buy more spare parts, including those for foreign cars as Mercedes, Opel, etc., and enlarge his shop's inventory. He promises to repay this loan within 15 months.

loans.use: Increase the inventory of spare parts for sale

loans.name: Magidu

texts.en:
B. Magidu, 35, is married with 4 children. He started his video library in Rukoki 3 years ago.  In addition, he also earns side income from repairing electrical appliances like radios, telsets, etceteras.

This loan will help Magidu increase his stock of videos and allow him to purchase a tool box for repairing electrical appliances.  He dreams of opening up a shop for electrical appliances and also hopes to construct a residential house on his piece of land.

loans.use: Purchase videos and a tool box for repairing electrical appliances.

loans.name: Sahib

texts.en: Sahib A. is a 39-year-old married man who lives with his wife and three children and owns a small farm. He lives and works in the small village of Saatli, Azerbaijan. Sahib has a business raising and selling calves. He has more that 20 years of experience in this field. Because calf-raising and -selling is a profitable business, Sahib has become a very successful businessman in a very short period of time. He works very hard and spends all his time with the calves, cleaning, feeding and pasturing them. Now, Sahib wants to expand his business and buy more calves, so he has applied for a loan of 1200 USD. With your help, Sahib can get ahead.

loans.use: purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Rizvan

texts.en: Rizvan R. is 55 years old and lives in small village of the Saatli region in Azerbaijan. He is the father of five children, and his main work consists of breeding cattle. He has had this business for more than 15 years. This very good activity enables him to provide for the needs of his family. A very ambitious man, he would like to buy a greater number of cattle and build a farmhouse to house them in order to ensure their safety. Due to a lack of finances, he is asking for a loan of 1200 USD for the realization of this project. He promises to repay the loan in 15 months. When his dream is carried out, he will be able to have a greater source of revenue for his big family. With your help this will be possible.

loans.use: purchase four calves

loans.name: Kamran

texts.en: Kamran A. is 37 years old. He is married with newly born son. He is a small entrepreneur who sells different kinds of foodstuffs, with the priority of selling candies in his store. His store is very famous in his community, thus allowing him to have a good clientele. Today Kamran is requesting a loan of 1200 USD for the term of 15 months to increase his stock. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. Kamran’s main goal is to provide better life to his family and in the future educate his beloved son so that someday he’ll become successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory for his store

loans.name: Jamal

texts.en: Jamal A. is a young, energetic man. At the early age of 21, he started his own business in order to support his parents. His business is selling home products in his own store in small village of Saatli city, Azerbaijan. This business allows him not only to support his household but also to continue to get more experienced in this trade. Jamal needs to increase the variety of goods he sells and is asking for a loan of 1200 USD with a term of 12 months. This loan will allow him to expand his business and earn more income. This loan will be an important part in the growth of Jamal’s business.

loans.use: purchase more food inventory and home products

loans.name: Mekhti

texts.en: Mekhti B. lives in a small village of Saatli, Azerbaijan. He is 40 years old, married, and has three children. Mekhti is the sole provider for his family and earns his living by raising and selling livestock. Every year he purchases young calves from local livestock bazaar, raises them for 8 or 9 months, and then sells the adult cows and bulls to local butchers or bazaar traders. Today Mekhti is thinking about expanding his business because his current earnings are not enough to provide for his family. He wants to purchase more calves and fodder. That’s why he is requesting a loan of 1200 USD. Extend your solidarity to Mekhti so that he can move forth successfully and accomplish all his goals.

loans.use: purchase two cattle

loans.name: Kamran

texts.en: Kamran A. is 39 years of age. He lives with his wife and three children. Kamran has been breeding livestock for nine years. Thanks to this activity, he can cover his living expenses. He goes out every morning to graze his animals. He enjoys caring for his animals, and he is grateful that this work puts food on the table for his children. Kamran’s family is his greatest love, and they are the biggest motivators in his life. He will use the loan to purchase young cattle, which will revitalize his herd and help him become the best breeder in his area. With your help this will be possible.

loans.use: purchase two calves

loans.name: Shaiq

texts.en: Shaiq Q. has a little shop where he sells different kind of food and goods for the home. He started his business 1995. Shaiq is married and has 5 daughters. He loves his daughters and wishes to give all of them the best education he can. He is a very cheerful person, and he is always glad to meet anyone who comes into his shop. All his clients are satisfied with his service. Shaiq tries to make his assortment of food products more competitive. In the near future he dreams of expanding his business and buying more foodstuffs. Right now, however, he is requesting 1200 USD. This loan will be an important part of the growth of Shaiq’s business.

loans.use: purchase more food inventory to resell

loans.name: Habil

texts.en: Habil is a very optimistic man in spite of the circumstances he has endured. He is 47 years old and married with five children. Habil raises cattle, and he uses his the income to support his family’s expenses. He has a great appreciation for animals, and Habil wishes to increase his cattle and therefore increase his earnings. He hopes that you can help him by funding his loan. You could become an important part of his family's life. Hobil deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

loans.use: purchase two calves
